text: I have many 2D arrays filled with numbers of type UInt16. When I subtract two of them using `.-` syntax *sometimes* it spits out way bigger numbers than it should (but not always...). If I manually loop through the arrays and convert each entry to Float64 before doing the subtraction however it works fine? Anybody know why this might be happening?

text:
Unsigned integers are not the recommended data structure to represent integers upon which you want to perform "normal" arithmetic operations, because they *wrap around*.

If you wanted to give them the charitable interpretation of being strictly positive integers, what would you expect the result of subtracting a larger UInt from a smaller UInt to be? Julia doesn't perform automatic type promotion, so the result wouldn't be very meaningful.

Observe this in action:
```julia> first_uint = 0x0010
0x0010

julia> Int(first_uint)
16

julia> second_uint = 0x0020
0x0020

julia> Int(second_uint)
32

julia> first_uint - second_uint
0xfff0

julia> Int(first_uint - second_uint)
65520```

I assume that what you really want is real subtraction or truncated subtraction-- either way you should represent your data with a signed integer or a float.

A single pre-processing step after you obtain your data should suffice:
```a_better_array = Int32.(my_uint_array)```
